awd_titl_txt: Scaffolding Undergraduate Curriculum and Career Exploration for Science Success
awd_abstract_narration:
With funds from NSF's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) program, Viterbo University in Lacrosse, Wisconsin, will improve educational opportunities in STEM areas for low-income, talented rural students by preparing these students to help address the many current global environmental and ecological challenges that face the United States. This S-STEM Capacity Building project will award scholarships and provide community and academic support to two cohorts of eleven students each for majors in biology or environmental biology. The underlying impetus of the project will be to recruit, enroll, retain, prepare, and graduate more biological sciences majors, especially from rural areas, for employment or graduate programs in the sciences. 

The investigators will provide resources for student success by providing students with: (a) financial, community, and academic support; (b) traditional and cutting edge scientific knowledge and skills; (c) real world work experiences through internships and research opportunities; and (d) specific resources needed to transition to the STEM workforce or graduate programs in related science fields. The project team will implement, study, and assess a scaffolding approach which will include: (i) early academic interventions for students to help overcome deficits in preparation; (ii) retain science students to graduation through social motivation and professional advocacy; (iii) provide students relevant, high impact experiences including job shadowing, internships and undergraduate research experiences, and (iv) Graduate well-prepared science students and assist them in obtaining employment or further education in their target field. To evaluate and advance understanding of the impact of the various activities, specifically concerning rural students, the project team will use a qualitative and quantitative mixed-methods research approach to investigate and measure a variety of impact variables including financial and the other support opportunities. The program has been designed to: promote broadening participation for talented, low-income rural students; build capacity and be sustainable at Viterbo; and be replicable at similar institutions that serve rural populations.

por.por_cntn:
Viterbo University was awarded approximately $650,000 through the NSF S-STEM program to support the recruitment, support, and development of biology, neuroscience, and biochemistry majors who would be prepared for employment or entrance into graduate programs in the sciences. Viterbo largely recruits students from a rural population with many of our students being first-generation college students. During the grant period, 93% of students enrolled at Viterbo were from a county which was at least 70% rural according to the U.S. Census data of 2010 and 37% were first-generation college students. These University statistics align with the make-up of our SUCCESS scholar cohorts and as a result, one of our core goals was to understand best approaches to support rural STEM students? success. Our efforts focused on providing overlapping high impact practices that were integrated into students? academic program and shown by the primary literature to be effective in the retention of STEM students. These efforts alongside the scholarship support endeavored to provide students resources and tools necessary to succeed at college and enter the STEM workforce.

Scholars who participated in the S-STEM grant received scaffolded experiences to support their academic success while concurrently exploring possible STEM career options. For example, in their first and second-years scholars enrolled in a one-credit course alongside their major-related coursework. In the first year that course focused on developing their study and note taking approaches, test taking strategies, and time management skills. It also introduced students to campus resources such as the library, academic resource center, campus life, and student support offices and personnel. While in their second year, the course examined science careers, internships, interviewing and networking skills, research opportunities and writing CVs and cover letters. Throughout their academic experience the scholars existed as a cohort. They had classes as a group, attended lectures and social activities together, and participated in outreach events collectively. This intentional community building was aimed at the goal of developing social cohesion and peer support. Additionally, the scholars had access to peer tutoring for all their coursework to provide intentional academic support. In their later classes, scholars participated in panel discussions led by alums in the STEM field and regional STEM industry leaders helping them explore and see themselves in STEM related careers. For those interested in post-graduate studies, scholars traveled to regional graduate schools and were invited to register for a credit-bearing course that prepared students for the GRE. Finally, all scholars were given opportunities to participate in undergraduate research mentored by faculty at Viterbo or data-driven internships in the community. These opportunities helped scholars gain real-world experiences in addition to having strong academic preparation on their applications for employment or post-graduate programs.

Our grant saw a total of 28 students participate in all or portions of the efforts described above. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, changes to our academic program offerings, change in personnel and academic leadership, and the financial strain caused by the economic downturn, not all students participated in all the activities. Currently, 68% of the participants have or are on track to graduate with a STEM degree. Qualitative interviews conducted throughout the grant with the scholars helped identify aspects that were important in helping the scholars succeed in their academic and career goals.  First and foremost, all scholars emphasized the importance of the financial scholarship from the grant in helping them achieve their academic goals. Surveys and interviews also communicated the importance of the guided internship and research experiences students participated in that helped them envision what a career in STEM would entail. Finally, the two one-credit courses that provided scholars with tangible academic and career training and support were highlighted as factors in their success.

As a result of the findings and activities of the grant, we have institutionalized several aspects of the grant. Both one-credit courses for STEM are now offered each year to first- and second-year STEM majors. These courses aim to provide both avenues for cohort building, academic readiness skill building, exposure to resume and academic writing, access to information about REUs and internships, and career shadowing and development opportunities. We continue to offer and expand access to our peer-tutoring for all first- and second-year STEM classes with student tutors attending lectures to build relationships and invite students to supplemental sessions. Finally, the STEM departments are intentionally preparing upperclassmen for post-graduate placement in STEM jobs and programs. We take yearly trips for interested students to regional institutions for students to visit post-graduate programs. We also continue to have students participate in mentored research opportunities with faculty and support interested students in finding relevant internships or shadowing experiences to prepare them for the STEM jobs post-graduation.

In summary, our findings support the approach of overlapping high impact practices can result in greater student success within the STEM field.


Last Modified: 11/18/2022
Modified by: Michael S Alfieri
